subtitle: Hello, I'm Jeffrey Mishlove and welcome
to summer.
Today is Monday, I'm recording this
monologue today for release on Tuesday,
so I have gone through my complete backlog
because I've been traveling. For those
of you who might be curious, I went back
to visit the city where I used to live
just a short 6 months ago in Las Vegas,
Nevada. There I got to see a
wonderful play, Hamilton. Hamilton has
taken Broadway theater to a whole new
level. I used to think this is crazy,
people are paying $1,000 for tickets in
New York? But now having seen the play I
understand why. It's going to become a
real classic, just the way that Westside
Story has become a classic, or South
Pacific has become a major Broadway
classic. Hamilton is destined for that. Or
Phantom of the Opera.
It's just a magnificent piece of theater.
While I was in Las Vegas,
I got to hear Aarone Neville perform as
well. One of the great, greatest… one of
the greatest vocalists ever to appear in
the pop music scene. Even though... I
think he's 77 years old now, it was just
magnificent to hear him. He doesn't quite
have the pipes I think that he used to
have, but what technique, what style.So,
the thing is, my summer is probably like
yours, I have some travel scheduled and
that's going to make it a little
difficult for me to keep up with these
daily monologues. In fact, on top of the
travel that I have scheduled, I am
preparing a course. The course is
titled, "William James and the Science of
Consciousness." It is a course for the
organization called The Holmes Institute.
I've been teaching for the Holmes
Institute now for, I think, over 20 years…
for over 20 years.
It's an organization, a distant learning
accredited college program that offers
master's degrees for ministers in
training with a church called The
Centers for Spiritual Living. [It] used to be
known as the United Church of Religious
Science and the International Church of
Religious Science. Many decades ago
this organization had a schism and
it was split into two separate
organizations. Now, they've reunited and
in so doing have changed their name from
the Church of Religious Science, the
publishers for those of you who may be
curious of the Mind Science Magazine, now
it is known as the Center for Spiritual
Living.My course on parapsychology
is one of the regular courses that is
taken by, I think everyone, or almost
everyone who receives a minister's
degree through that church. Now, I'm not a
member of the church. I'm not much of a
joiner. I describe myself in other
monologues as basically a secular Jew.
But I'm very fond of these people. They
have ongoing, they're called Religious
Science practitioners, or they used to be
called… they're healers. They train
lay members of the church to practice
the art of psychic and spiritual healing.
They have healers at work 24 hours a
day is my understanding, sending healing
thoughts.So, it's going to be a little
erratic for me uploading both the video
conversations and the "In Presence"
monologues over the summer. I hope
you'll be patient with me, we'll get back
on a regular schedule in the fall
once again. I', going to do my best to
keep these uploads coming as rapidly as
I can. I just
don't think it's realistic that I'll be
keeping up the same pace. So, bear with me
over the summer. But what I will try to
do in order to keep things going is to
take advantage of the fact that I'm
developing this course and include some
of the material that will go into the
course lecture as part of the uploads.
An interesting place to start today
is on what is known as the New England
or American Transcendentalist Movement.
Because you can't really understand
William James without understanding the
American Transcendentalists, the New
England Transcendentalists. This is a
very important philosophical and
literary movement. It had a major
influence on William James and his whole
family and it's very important in terms
of understanding American culture,
because this is really native American
mysticism. I'm talking about the school
of thought that included Ralph Waldo
Emerson, Henry David Thoreau, and many
other writers. In fact, it spawned several
churches. It spawned the Christian
Science movement. It spawned the Unity
Church. It spawned the Church of
Religious Science. All of that came out
of what was known as the New Thought
Movement, which was closely aligned with
the American Transcendentalist Movement.
It came out of New England in the middle
of the 19th century, or the latter half
of the 19th century. What you
had there are basic ideas that people
can change their lives by changing the
way they think. You can change your life
by changing your attitudes, your beliefs
and your thought patterns. That's
the fundamental of it, right there.
I've just given you New Thought in a nutshell.
It's not as if you have to subscribe to
any dogmas, but it's about thinking
positively, it's about giving yourself
positive mental suggestions. You could
say it's an outgrowth of Mesmerism, an
outgrowth of hypnosis. In fact, really one
of the leading figures of this movement,
a very obscure fellow named Phineas
Quimby. He practiced hypnosis and he, in
fact, hypnotized Mary Baker Eddy who then
founded the Church of Christian Science.
It was out of Quimby's work that
these other religious movements
developed as well.So, then the question
is, well what is the relationship between
New Thought, positive thinking in other
words, like Emile Coue in France was a
psychologist of sorts at that time, who
developed this phrase: "Every day in every
way I am getting better and better."
People could just repeat that to
themselves. It had the effect of, what
John Lilly would have called, programming
the human biocomputer. "Every day in
every way I'm getting better and better."
Positive thinking. The New Thought
movement. It's very American. It's very
much in alignment with William James'
Pragmatic philosophy. But the
Transcendentalist Movement was a little
more mystical than that. Really, the
godfather, I think, of American
Transcendentalism is Ralph Waldo
Emerson. Well, he was known as a great
essayist. He wrote essays. What people
often don't know about Emerson is that
he in effect channeled these essays. He
would go into a kind of half awake state
and, as he put it, the brownies, the
brownies did the writing for him. It was
like automatic writing. He'd be half
awake and he'd be just,
you know, the pen would be moving and
he's not even thinking about it. It's
coming from what you could call the
superconscious mind. His essays were
very elegant, very uplifting. The American
Transcendentalists were also to a large
extent very interested in the theology
of the Church of the New Jerusalem,
founded by the Swedish mystic, the 18th
century Swedish mystic, Emanuel
Swedenborg, the Swedenborgian Church. Now,
it's not that the church itself was so
different from any of the other churches
that were around at the time, but
Swedenbourg himself, the founder of the
church, was a relatively contemporary
figure. That's what we began to see
with Mary Baker Eddy and the Mormon
Church and the Church of Religious
Science and the Unity Church. It was
a time, in the 19th century, 18th
century, when new religions were being
founded, here on the North American
continent. It's interesting that that
should happen. It's a sense of the
vitality of the human spirit that these
religions were being founded. Even
today, in our so-called postmodern age,
you still see new religions being
founded. What does that say about us?
It says that our religious imagination
is very fertile, that we're not going to
simply accept what has been handed to us
historically. But, we're going to
introduce a new creative element into
the global religious heritage that is
the inheritance of every one of us.
That's my viewpoint. I think I made it
clear on other occasions as well, even
though I consider myself a secular
person, a secular Jew, I also believe that
the great spiritual traditions of the
entire planet
are my inheritance and your inheritance.
As such, we have an obligation to
study them, to understand our inheritance.
But even more so an obligation to
interact creatively with that
inheritance.The life of William
James, who I mentioned earlier in
a previous "In Presence" segment, deserves
repetition over and over again. What a
role model he was, one of America's
greatest philosophers. But more than that,
basically the founder, the father of
experimental psychology in the United
States, and theoretical psychology in the
United States. But more than that, even,
the founder of the academic or
scientific study of religious and
spiritual traditions. That's a lot for
one man to have done. That's one of
the reasons that I consider him a hero. Well,
even more than all of that, he was one of
the founders of the American Society for
Psychical Research, a President of the
Society for Psychical Research in
England, and obviously one of the great
creative thinkers in American history.
But, a very important person for my field
of parapsychology as well. So, I'll be
talking more about that as we go on.
But for now, let me leave you with this
thought. Given that, as I've said, the
world's spiritual religions and
traditions are your inheritance, what are
you going to do about that inheritance?
How are you going to interact with the
global spiritual traditions? Does it make
sense to you to even consider being open
to that vast body of not just literature,
but music, art,
sculpture, architecture? Religions have
played such an enormous part in human
culture. How do you plan to interact
creatively with that inheritance? I'll
leave you with that thought. Thank you
once again for being with me.
